Topic.Title: It really wasn't THAT long ago..

Message.Msg: I think WS was stunned by the early signs of deterioration revealed at QC earnings cc. Not only that, I also read an article stating that NV's upcoming Tegra 4i, whose end devices are to be sold at prices below $200, could cut into QC's royalty income stream (mostly on CDMA/3G communication chips). I have no way to ascertain the degree of damage quantitative, but certainly can appreciate the point on a qualitative basis. So... --LTE: Competition catching up (NVDA, BRCM) --CDMA/3G: royalty income stream steadily declining... And QC is not battle trained as NV is....

Topic.Title: It really wasn't THAT long ago..

Message.Msg: Nvidia ex cash is a cheap company with 10% of qcom valuation. They are supposed to be an ok competition to qcom. Just taking some market shares from qcom could skyrocket nvda share. But really wondering why it takes them so long to do a good job? And the integration of LTE chips. I thought tegra 4 would do it. Why not? And When will it be ready? Anyway, with a decent technical chart set up and with semis showing bullishness, Nvidia better not screw up this time round.

Topic.Title: Max

Message.Msg: I hope I don't come across as an SA fan or someone that sponsors Ashraf here, because I'm neither, but I don't get the need to dwell so much on Ashraf or for that matter other posters who have come and gone (and come back) that imo have plenty of input and information to share whether you agree with them or not. We all trade or invest in several companies' stocks I would imagine, maybe not within one industry per se, so I just don't see how it is good to basically insult someone that seems mostly competent in their comments and respectful. Sure, they may be wrong or take an angle we may think is not totally honest but if their information is solid or at least shows some research, why be so insulting or condescending at times? I admit, I'm insulting and condescending at times, but it's usually in response to someone's own bashing and immature statements. I'm pretty sure Ashraf, from his last responses that I've read, is not shamed at all but more insulted, and doesn't see the point in responding at this point. Anyways, I really do appreciate max's comments (as well as ibexx and others for the most part on this board) and hope he gets all the time with his family that he needs. I lost my mother late in 2011 and it was not an easy time for me either. Regards . .

Topic.Title: Blooody XC, whosnw & chrisssy is super hated!

Message.Msg: we buy stocks based on potential. but one has to keep not just an open mind, but set up signposts that the company needs to hit on its way of realizing the potential. These signposts cannot be this chip or that. Or this design win or that. These signposts must be market penetration and sales because the end user market is the one who does the final judging. This way one can remain objective. Take brcm and nvda. Brcm's mobile strategy of fully integrated solutions is almost hitting the signposts. Late, but very encouraging. Their 3G chips are in Samsung phones and have been adopted in India. The share price pop after earnings was due to that. I hope they can get into China too. This will prove that their strategy has merit and is worth waiting around for. Nvda, on the other hand, has missed all the signposts. Nvda chased the high end and totally flopped: the high end tablet market has segmented into something that will not support any other 3rd party silicon. The high end phone market is mature and saturated, all without nvda being able to get a toehold. If nvda tries to swim downstream, like with the T3i, there is only so much space to go before they run into brcm's targeted space. Icera is a huge success, but you won't hear Jen talk about it. nvda is calling modem sales 'Tegra sales' and hoping nobody can see through that. Losing Nexus 7 is huge. That is the one and only Tegra device selling that has any kind of run rates. And longs here say it does not matter? You can't expect yourself to be taken seriously if you spout stuff like that. "How do you model Tegra sales?"

Topic.Title: POS nvidia

Message.Msg: Short term, some phone and tablet wins are what NVDA needs to really progress. I wouldn't expect really notable wins for a few more months based on the T4i schedule, so I expect range-bound performance. On the other hand, some of the T4 sightings and previews are starting to look good. Much as the expected Nexus 7 loss is unfortunate, the Nexus line has shown weakness. The Nexus 10, for example, is rarely seen compared to the Asus 10" table which sports a T3. So, there is definitely life outside of Nexus. I hold INTC, NVDA, and will likely pick up AMD soon. All for very different reasons. MHO.

Message.Title: Latest rumor about Google X phone - Tegra 4i in it
Message.Msg: ""Google X-Phone Finally, the Motorola acquisition starts to make sense. Or does it? It is rumored that the X-Phone is set for release this year. The device will supposedly have a 4.7-inch Full HD display, and will get the power from an Nvidia Tegra 4i multi-core processor clocked at 2.3 GHz, and a 16MP camera. It is believed that this will be first new phone with the Android Key Lime Pie OS version, but we will take that, like all rumours with a pinch of salt – mostly because, the Nexus 5 is also being talked about quite a bit."" SOURCE: thinkdigitDOTcom/Mobiles-PDAs/Forward-Looking-Gadgets-to-look-out-for_14476.html

Message.Title: ARMH: processor share and royalty rate to rise, says analyst
Message.Msg: SOURCE: Barrons just in "By Tiernan Ray Shares of Canaccord Genuity’s Matthew Ramsay this morning reiterates a Buy rating on shares of chip intellectual property licensor ARM Holdings (ARMH), and a $52 price target, writing that his recent meetings with investors regarding the stock in Milwaukee, Chicago, Kansas City, and Denver were “upbeat,” and that he maintains a view the company is “is well positioned to hold dominant processor market share within the growing smartphone and tablet markets while benefitting from royalty rate expansion due to increased Cortex-A penetration, Mali graphics attach rates, and secular trends toward chipset integration.” Ramsay sees ARM increasing its share of microprocessors by the end of this decade to more than 50% from 32% at present, and he sees the company’s royalty rate will rise to 1.5% next year from 1.3% last year, on average, and may approach 2% at the end of the decade. ARM shares today are up $1.03, or 2.2%, at $47.78. _______ Posting this as general information, as well as for our "esteemed" SA blogger who is heavily short ARMH by his own account. So far, unfortunately, Blogger #2 has been deadly wrong on several accounts (QCOM, ARMH most notably). Er....well, as long as the SA folks aren't aware of it....

Message.Title: "AMD surges as Intel, XBox talk surfaces: report"
Message.Msg: "AMD surges as Intel, XBox talk surfaces: report" "As U.S. stocks tumbled Wednesday on fears the economy is stalling again, and at the start of the traditional “sell-in-May” season, Advanced Micro Devices bucked the trend noticeably. AMD stock AMD +0.31% rose 14.2% to close at $3.22 a share, its highest close since Oct. 9. The percentage gain was AMD’s biggest since July 22, 2011, when it jumped 19.2%. Barron’s Tech Trader Daily noted the resurgence of speculation that Intel could move to buy AMD, noting that anti-trust issues are less of a concern than in earlier years because the personal computing space is broader than it was when WinTel dominated technology. Other speculation has centered on new game console from Microsoft MSFT 0.00% due to be announced later this month that could use AMD chips. There’s also substantial short interest in AMD, about 20%, Tech Trader Daily noted. AMD reported a narrower first-quarter loss on April 18, and forecast second-quarter revenue would range from a 5% gain to a 1% loss, vs. the first quarter." Source: Marketwatch

Topic.Title: "AMD surges as Intel, XBox talk surfaces: report"

Message.Msg: The royalty check is required by the legal settlement; think of it as NVDA's pay-off to be shut out of the x86 chipset market a few years ago and not to yell "anti-trust" too loudly. Read the details before you invest anything based on the idea that it would go away. An AMD buy-out would likely accelerate the collapse of the discrete video card market for all but the high-end. That is already happening and NVDA is working to develop other opportunities, but it would push the collapse forward enough that NVDA would be challenged to be ready. What do you guess, 18 months to see ATI graphics make their way into INTC processors, if a deal happened? On the other hand, it wouldn't really change anything about Tegra or supercomputers. I know, you don't believe Tegra is real. LOL. AMD is struggling for relevancy in both those markets. IMO, it would speed up a transition that is happening anyway. Anyone investing in NVDA based on the future of discrete graphics was on the wrong track anyway.

Topic.Title: ARMH: processor share and royalty rate to rise, says analyst

Message.Msg: It's funny...as an Nvidia bull you should be thinking, "Gee, but if Tegra takes significant market share, then ARM doesn't get Mali royalties, undermining a portion of this thesis!" Further, do you actually think that it's a good thing for Nvidia that royalty rates will get ridiculous, especially as wafer cost increases are NOT offset by the traditional scaling benefits in the 20nm generation and, more markedly in the "16nm" generation? For a guy who likes to talk trash, you sure have your head where the sun don't shine. I like Nvidia, but it's funny how you're taking out the pain you feel from xc's attacks on me ;)
